Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Development of a Large-scale Process for Production of Vault-Stabilized Enzymes for Industrial Uses and Environmental Cleanup
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project is to develop a large-scale process for production of vault-stabilized enzymes. This project will develop a new nanoparticle-based technology for stabilizing enzymes so that they can be used for industrial applications and environmental cleanup such as water treatment. By employing a scalable, high yield, low cost manufacturing system for vault-enzymes, the company would be able to deploy a variety of new products into the field for treating certain environmental pollutants in drinking water, groundwater, wastewater, and reclaimed water. This would give environmental engineers and regulatory agencies new tools to clean and protect national natural resources and public health.

The technical objectives in this Phase I research project are to develop a yeast-based production system for nano-scale vault particles. Vault nanoparticles are promising candidates to stabilize and enhance the performance of enzymes for catalytic industrial applications and biotransformation. The packaging of enzymes into vault particles combines enzyme purification and immobilization into a single manufacturing step, and is a cost-effective, environmentally friendly approach for immobilizing and protecting enzymes. Demonstrating feasibility of this system will allow simple integration of vault-enzymes into industrial manufacturing systems and would allow vault enzyme prototypes to be rapidly scaled up and deployed for specific environmental remediation targets.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report:

Enzymes are highly efficient biocatalysts that have been applied in a broad range of commercial products and industrial processes including bioremediation of polluted materials and landscapes. Vault particles are bio-particles found in most eukaryotes. Vault packaging of enzymes combines enzyme purification and immobilization into a single manufacturing step, and is a promising cost-effective and environmentally friendly approach for immobilizing and protecting enzymes. Additionally vault particles are dynamic structures that can enhance the effectiveness of enzyme substrate reaction kinetics.  Current production of vault particles, accomplished in baculovirus infected insect cells, is costly, and has limited potential for industrial manufacturing.

The novel aspects of this proposal include exploring production of vault particles in low-cost and scalable expression system and testing the enzymes stabilized in vaults for biodegrading water contaminants. We demonstrated a novel vault manufacturing processes that are compatible with high capacity industrial manufacturing systems and would allow vault enzyme prototypes to be rapidly and cost-effectively scaled up and deployed for specific environmental remediation targets. Vault enzymes were produced and successfully reduced endocrine disrupting phenolic contaminants. We are seeking to continue this development to apply highly effective and biodegradable technology to consumable water purification, specifically removal of endocrine disrupting trace contaminants such as non-physiologic estrogen mimetics.

In terms of broader impact, vault-enzymes provide an ideal environmental remediation technology due to the elegant all-protein structure of vaults, which is biodegradable, thereby limiting concerns for a long-term environmental footprint. As a broad nano-delivery platform technology, vault-based stabilization and protection of enzymes is not restricted to the application in environmental remediation. Once the feasibility of a high-yield industrially compatible and cost effective vault production system is established, it could be easily adapted to the food industry, cosmetic manufacturing, biofuel production, as well as other enzyme-mediated chemical engineering processes. Additionally, because of their biological origins, vaults could be used for stabilizing enzymes in commercially produced agro-based and other natural products, such as digestive supplements and detergents.

 


Last Modified: 07/11/2018
Modified by: Oliver Foellmer
